title: Play Talk: Sonya Hale on self-care, setbacks and overcoming addiction
text:
22/22 Harry Potter and the Cursed Child 
'A magical experience' Manuel Harlan What’s been the biggest surprise to you since you’ve had your writing performed by actors? It never ceases to amaze me that actors take the time and effort to perform my words. When I think about it it's bonkers. What’s been your biggest setback as a writer? I can’t think of one! I didn't make it into the BBC Writers Room a few years ago but I don't think I was ready. Setbacks are to be expected I think it's important to just keep going. And the hardest lesson you’ve had to learn? Self-care, rest, moderation… How to nurture myself as a writer. What do you think is the best thing about theatre? And the worst? Play Talk: Kirsten Childs on writing a musical about an outsider The best thing about theatre is that it's live, it's in the moment and it's about as close to life as you can get without being in it. When it's at its best it's so exciting. The worst thing about theatre is the middle-class stuffy attitude that goes with it. I sometimes get the feeling people like to watch plays about disadvantaged people struggling but don't always welcome it in the real-life audience. I took my son to the theatre once and when he called his cousin sat next to him a 'waste-man' the man on the other side tutted and said my son's behaviour was disgusting. I have written a lot of plays for fringe theatres and all my mates used to come and watch in a right rabble, munching on their pop-corn, drinking coke. It was such a lovely inclusive atmosphere. What’s your best piece of advice for writers who are starting out? Keep writing, just keep writing and give yourself permission to write absolutely shit. Write and write and write and write and only then go back and edit it. Have fun, play with it and don't take heed of the vicious inner critic. Are there any themes and stories you find yourself re-visiting with your plays? Yes. Loss. A lot. And sexuality. Feminist issues. And finding forgiveness. Arts picks of the week: 13th-19th February Arts picks of the week: 13th-19th February 1/8 Twelfth Night 
Director Simon Godwin’s Twelfth Night switches up gender, with interesting implications for the love stories within the play. Malvolio becomes Malvolia, played by Tamsin Grieg, with Phoebe Fox and Oliver Chris also starring. Read what director Simon Godwin had to say about "embarking on a fascinating jungle". From February 15, National Theatre; nationaltheatre.org.uk 2/8 Wolfgang Tillmans 
Wolfgang Tillmans’ work is always rich with political urgency. The artist created a series of posters urging voters to rethink leaving the EU last year, and this major exhibition of his work at Tate Modern uses 2003, the year of the Iraq war, as its departure point. February 15 - June 11, Tate Modern; tate.org.uk 3/8 Eduardo Paolozzi 
Paolozzi’s sculptures can be found all over London, but a major retrospective at Whitechapel Gallery throws a light on more of his work. Expansive with over 250 pieces, it features collages, sculptures and prints. February 16 - May 14, Whitechapel Gallery; whitechapelgallery.org 4/8 A Midsummer Night's Dream 
A Joe Hill-Gibbins production is always worth seeing. What will he make of A Midsummer Night’s Dream? The Young Vic say he’s reaching into the subconscious of Shakespeare’s masterpiece. Last time he did that with Measure for Measure, Romola Garai fought her way across a stage full of blow up sex dolls. Read his thoughts on demystifying Shakespeare. February 16 - April 1, Young Vic; youngvic.org 5/8 Low Level Panic 
Clare McIntyre’s blistering study of what life was like in the 1980s for women is still relevant today. The first major revival since its Royal Court premiere opens at the Orange Tree Theatre in Richmond this week. Evening Standard Theatre Award nominee Sophie Melville stars - she talks about the play here . February 16 - March 25, Orange Tree Theatre; orangetreetheatre.co.uk 6/8 The Sick of the Fringe 
The Wellcome Collection are helping bring this Edinburgh Fringe fixture to London, exploring the connections between health and art. A weekend of mostly free events will cover topics from mental health to incontinence. February 17-19, venues across London; wellcomecollection.org.uk/sickofthefringe 7/8 The Hermes Experiment 
This contemporary quartet are marking the Russian Revolution centenary with an evening of music that marks historic turning points. The evening at King’s Place will see them perform new arrangements of Mosolov, Prokofiev and Rachmaninoff, as well as a new piece inspired by the works of the Russian avante-garde happening at the time. February 16, King’s Place; kingsplace.co.uk 8/8 LGBTQ Histories at the British Museum 
The British Museum are kicking off a year of events celebrating LGBTQ people with a talk from one of their curators on the LGBTQ objects in their permanent collection. It kicks off with a talk from curator Laura Phillips, shedding light on some of the things found in upcoming exhibition Desire Love Identity: Exploring LGBTQ Histories. February 14, British Museum; britishmuseum.org Are you on Twitter? Do you find it a help or a hindrance as a writer? No I'm not. I'm a bit stuck in the stone age. I only got my first proper tele for Christmas and still haven't switched it on. My son is not impressed... Why did you write Glory Whispers? Because I felt I had to. I think I needed to make sense in some way of all the loss and pain I had experienced in my addiction but I also think that this need to write was compounded by the way addicts and homeless people and the disadvantaged are often misrepresented in theatre. I feel like real voices need to speak out, write and tell things a bit more as it is. How do you spend opening night? Biting my nails.
